literal: You! The one naked, what do you need? I need a ring made of gold my lord.
equivalent: Putting the cart before the horse.
darija_ar: أش خاصك يا العريان, خاصني خاتم الذهب يا مولاي.
eng_equivalent: Mind your own business.
eng_literal: What do you want, you naked one, give me the gold ring, sir.
darija_equivalent: Mind your own business.
darija_literal: What's your problem, you naked person, my concern is the gold ring, sir.

literal: One bitten by a snake will fear a cord.
equivalent: The burnt child dreads the fire.
darija_ar: اللي عضو الحنش كيخاف من الحبل.
eng_equivalent: The guilty dog barks the loudest.
eng_literal: The one who stole the beehive is afraid of the rope.
darija_equivalent: He who plays with fire gets burned.
darija_literal: The one who bites the snake is afraid of the rope.

literal: He came to help her with her eyeliner and blinded her.
darija_ar: جا يكحلها عماها.
eng_equivalent: He came to put kohl on her eyes.
eng_literal: He came to fix it for her.
darija_equivalent: He's adding fuel to the fire.
darija_literal: He came to fix what he messed up.

literal: If one doesn't have money, their speech is tasteless.
darija_ar: اللي ما عندو فلوس كلامو مسوس.
eng_equivalent: Empty vessels make the most noise.
eng_literal: Whoever doesn't have money, their words are considered insignificant.
darija_equivalent: Empty vessels make the most noise.
darija_literal: Who doesn't have money, his words are worthless.

literal: Say nice things on your friend around others; chastise him face to face.
equivalent: Praise in public, criticize in private.
darija_ar: امدح صاحبك مع الناس ولومو الراس فالراس.
eng_equivalent: Speak well of your friend in public, but scold him in private.
eng_literal: Praise your friend in front of people and scold him in private.
darija_equivalent: Praise your friend in public and scold him in private.
darija_literal: Praise your friend in front of people and scold him in private.

literal: One eye saw and the other eye did not see.
darija_ar: دير عين شافت وعين ماشافت.
eng_equivalent: Out of sight, out of mind.
eng_literal: Put an eye that sees and an eye that doesn't see.
darija_equivalent: Out of sight, out of mind.
darija_literal: Put an eye that sees and an eye that doesn't see.

literal: Put a plastic bag on your eye.
darija_ar: دير عين ميكا.
eng_equivalent: Mind your own business.
eng_literal: Put some eye makeup.
darija_equivalent: Keep an eye out.
darija_literal: Put on your sunglasses.

literal: You don't feel the whip unless you are the one being beaten with it.
equivalent: You never know a man until you walk a mile in his shoes.
darija_ar: ما تيحس بالمزود غير اللي مخبوط به.
eng_equivalent: The shoe only pinches the foot that wears it.
eng_literal: You only feel the thorn that's stuck in you.
darija_equivalent: You never miss the water till the well runs dry.
darija_literal: You only feel the itch of the shirt you're wearing.

literal: Start them off with crayons.
darija_ar: خصك معاهم الخشيبات.
eng_equivalent: Mind your own beeswax.
eng_literal: Mind your own business with them old folks.
darija_equivalent: Mind your own business.
darija_literal: Mind your own business.

literal: Even the owner of the crown (the king) has needs.
equivalent: It rains on the rich and poor alike.
darija_ar: مول التاج كيحتاج.
eng_equivalent: The crown needs a head.
eng_literal: The mall needs renovation.
darija_equivalent: All that glitters is not gold.
darija_literal: The boss is in need.

literal: Think about it 101 times before cutting with the scissors.
darija_ar: مية تخميمة وتخميمة ولا ضربة بالمقص.
eng_equivalent: A shot in the dark.
eng_literal: A hundred guesses and not a single correct one, it's like a shot in the dark.
darija_equivalent: A hundred guesses are no match for one try.
darija_literal: A hundred guesses are like a hundred snips with scissors.

literal: If one wants honey, they must endure the sting of bees.
darija_ar: اللي بغي لعسل يصبر لقريص النحل.
eng_equivalent: If you want honey, be prepared to deal with bees.
eng_literal: Whoever wants honey should endure the sting of the bee.
darija_equivalent: If you want honey, be prepared to deal with bees.
darija_literal: Whoever wants honey should be patient with the bees' stings.

literal: A grand funeral for a dead mouse.
equivalent: Making a mountain out of a molehill.
darija_ar: الگنازة كبيرة والميت فار.
eng_equivalent: The funeral is grand, but the deceased is a mouse.
eng_literal: The funeral is big and the deceased is far.
darija_equivalent: The funeral is big and the deceased is a mouse.
darija_literal: The coffin is big and the dead person is small.

literal: One said to the other I tricked you and the other said I experienced you (for who you are).
equivalent: fool me once shame on you, fool me twice shame on me.
darija_ar: قالو شمتك، قالو جربتك.
eng_equivalent: They said you're bitter, he said they've tasted you.
eng_literal: They said they mocked you, they said they tried you.
darija_equivalent: They said you're a thorn, they said they tried you.
darija_literal: They said they envy you, they said they tried you.

literal: If you are raised with something you grow old with it.
darija_ar: اللي تربي على شي حاجة كبر عليها.
eng_equivalent: Familiarity breeds contempt.
eng_literal: Whoever is raised on something will grow accustomed to it.
darija_equivalent: You can't teach an old dog new tricks.
darija_literal: Whoever is raised on something will grow accustomed to it.

literal: One who dugs a hole fells into it.
darija_ar: لي حفر شي حفرة كيطيح فيها.
eng_equivalent: He who digs a pit will fall into it.
eng_literal: Who digs a hole, falls into it.
darija_equivalent: He who digs a pit will fall into it.
darija_literal: The one who digs a hole falls into it.

literal: The people are with the people and the bald guy is combing his hair.
darija_ar: الناس في الناس والقرع في مشيط الراس.
eng_equivalent: People will be people.
eng_literal: People are people, and the pumpkin is in the comb of the head.
darija_equivalent: People will be people, and a pumpkin will always be a squash.
darija_literal: People are people and the pumpkin is in the head massager.

literal: A day's wedding is a year's planning.
equivalent: Rome wasn't built in a day.
darija_ar: زواج ليلة تدبيره عام.
eng_equivalent: A marriage planned in haste will end in waste.
eng_literal: A wedding is planned in the evening.
darija_equivalent: A marriage of convenience.
darija_literal: A wedding planned in one night.

literal: The Fqih that we expect his blessing entered the Mosque while wearing his slippers.
equivalent: Don't judge a book by its cover.
darija_ar: الفقيه اللي نتسناو براكته دخل للجامع ببلغته.
eng_equivalent: A wise man changes his mind, a fool never will.
eng_literal: The scholar we were waiting for entered the mosque with his dignity.
darija_equivalent: The wise man we are waiting for entered the mosque with his slippers on.
darija_literal: The scholar we've been waiting for entered the mosque with his dignity.

literal: Tie your donkey with other donkeys, it will only learn to bray, neigh and from the path he'll stray.
equivalent: You're known by the company you keep.
darija_ar: اربط حمارك مع الحمير، يتعلم الشيق والنهيق وخرجان الطريق.
eng_equivalent: Tell me who your friends are, and I'll tell you who you are.
eng_literal: Tie your donkey with the other donkeys, it will learn the braying and neighing and stay on the road.
darija_equivalent: Tie your donkey with donkeys, it will learn the braying and the neighing and stay on the right path.
darija_literal: Tie your donkey with the donkeys, he will learn the braying and neighing and get out of the way.

literal: Flies do not enter a closed mouth.
darija_ar: الفم المسدود ما يدخلو دبان.
eng_equivalent: A closed mouth catches no flies.
eng_literal: A closed mouth doesn't let flies in.
darija_equivalent: A closed mouth catches no flies.
darija_literal: A closed mouth doesn't catch flies.
